content:
Sure, here is an example of how you might compare two SEM models using the lavaan package in R:
```
# Load the lavaan package
library(lavaan)

# Fit the first SEM model to the data
model1 <- ' 
  # Latent variables
  Anxiety =~ x1 + x2 + x3
  Depression =~ x4 + x5 + x6
  # Covariances
  Anxiety ~~ Depression
'
fit1 <- sem(model1, data = mydata)

# Fit the second SEM model to the data
model2 <- ' 
  # Latent variables
  Anxiety =~ x1 + x2 + x3
  Depression =~ x4 + x5 + x6
  Stress =~ x7 + x8 + x9
  # Covariances
  Anxiety ~~ Depression
  Anxiety ~~ Stress
  Depression ~~ Stress
'
fit2 <- sem(model2, data = mydata)

# Compare the fit indices of the two models
fitIndices(fit1, fit2)

# Compare the modification indices of the two models
modIndices(fit1, fit2)
```
In this example, the first model (`model1`) is a simple SEM model that includes two latent (unobserved) variables, Anxiety and Depression, and their covariances. The second model (`model2`) is a more complex SEM model that includes an additional latent variable, Stress, and its covariances with Anxiety and Depression. The `fitIndices()` function can be used to compare the overall fit of the two models, and the `modIndices()` function can be used to identify potential modifications or improvements to the models.
